content:
I cross-post a question I put on the nForum here.

Define a boolean rig as a rig such that x2=xx^{2}=xx2=x. The question is whether such a rig is necessarily commutative. Every boolean ring is commutative. They also show in this paper: The variety of Boolean semirings that boolean rigs which verify 1+x+x=11+x+x=11+x+x=1 are commutative. The only boolean rigs of cardinal â‰¤2\le 2â‰¤2 are 000, Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z and B={0,1}\mathbb{B}=\{0,1\}B={0,1} with 1+1=11+1=11+1=1 (you can interpret this with 0=0=0="False", 1=1=1="True", +=+ =+="exclusive disjunction", âˆ—=*=âˆ—="conjonction" whereas in Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z, âˆ—*âˆ— must be seen as the classical disjunction).

Therefore if a noncommutative boolean rig exists, it must be of cardinal â‰¥3\ge 3â‰¥3, not be a ring and not verify 1+x+x=11+x+x=11+x+x=1.

Seems a bit strange to call that a Boolean rig; "idempotent rig" seems more transparent to me.
Observe that the idempotent condition results in xyxy=xxyyxyxy = xxyyxyxy=xxyy; this is close enough to commutativity that one can see how it might collapse to commutativity in a bunch of special cases.
Let's try considering the free rig on two elements x,yx,yx,y, which has formal sums of words on those letters as elements, with products of these formal sums defined via distributivity. To get the free idempotent rig, we quotient by the congruence generated by {(s2,s)âˆ£sâˆˆâŸ¨x,yâŸ©}\{(s^2,s) \mid s \in \langle x,y \rangle \}{(s2,s)âˆ£sâˆˆâŸ¨x,yâŸ©}. Since this rig represents pairs of elements in arbitrary idempotent rigs (universal property of the free object), there exists a non-commutative idempotent rig if and only if this rig is not commutative, since commutativity is preserved under rig homomorphisms.
(I tried to check whether (xy,yx)(xy,yx)(xy,yx) is in this congruence, but haven't succeeded; see how you get on!)
Thanks, very good start! I'm gonna try.

I think not. Let MMM be an idempotent monoid which is not commutative (these exist). We think of the monoid operation on MMM as multiplication. Let Mâ€²=Mâˆª{0,âˆ}M' = M \cup \{0,\infty\}Mâ€²=Mâˆª{0,âˆ}. Extend the monoid structure on MMM to one on Mâ€²M'Mâ€² by setting mâ‹…0=0â‹…m=0â‹…0=0m \cdot 0 = 0\cdot m = 0 \cdot 0 = 0mâ‹…0=0â‹…m=0â‹…0=0 and mâ‹…âˆ=âˆâ‹…m=âˆâ‹…âˆ=âˆm \cdot \infty = \infty \cdot m = \infty \cdot \infty = \inftymâ‹…âˆ=âˆâ‹…m=âˆâ‹…âˆ=âˆ for mâˆˆMm \in MmâˆˆM, and âˆâ‹…0=0â‹…âˆ=âˆ\infty \cdot 0 = 0 \cdot \infty = \inftyâˆâ‹…0=0â‹…âˆ=âˆ. Then define addition on Mâ€²M'Mâ€² by making 000 be the additive identity (so x+0=0+x=xx + 0 = 0 + x = xx+0=0+x=x for all xâˆˆMâ€²x \in M'xâˆˆMâ€²), making âˆ\inftyâˆ an absorbing element (so x+âˆ=âˆ+x=âˆx + \infty = \infty + x = \inftyx+âˆ=âˆ+x=âˆ for all xâˆˆMâ€²x \in M'xâˆˆMâ€²), and setting m+n=âˆm + n = \inftym+n=âˆ for m,nâˆˆMm,n \in Mm,nâˆˆM. Then I believe that Mâ€²M'Mâ€² is an idempotent semiring which is not commutative.

@Tim Campion not enough info there to see that the free idempotent monoid on two generators is not commutative; once again it's sufficient to check the free such monoid on two generators, which should look like {1,x,y,xy,yx,xyx,yxy}\{1,x,y,xy,yx,xyx,yxy\}{1,x,y,xy,yx,xyx,yxy}; from your link it has 7 elements, so all of these are distinct, and so we indeed have non-commutativity. :ok:ğŸ»
Congrats @Tim Campion @Morgan Rogers (he/him) ! Problem solved so.

Incidentally, extending the reasoning means that the free idempotent rig on two generators is finite: its elements are formal sums of the elements of the free idempotent monoid, whose positive coefficients are reduced modulo 2 to 111 or 222, since 1+1âˆ¼1+1+1+11 + 1 \sim 1+1+1+11+1âˆ¼1+1+1+1 and hence 3âˆ¼9âˆ¼13 \sim 9 \sim 13âˆ¼9âˆ¼1 (note that we don't have 2âˆ¼02 \sim 02âˆ¼0 without subtraction!)
There are some further identifications here meaning that there are far fewer than 373^737 elements; for example, (x+y)2=x+y+xy+yxâˆ¼x+y(x+y)^2 = x + y +xy +yx \sim x+y(x+y)2=x+y+xy+yxâˆ¼x+y. I'm sure there's an algebra package that can handle a reduction to a neat explicit presentation. I wonder how many elements there are!
Maybe I'll pose that as a puzzle on Mathstodon!
How are you getting 3 âˆ¼\sim âˆ¼ 1, @Morgan Rogers (he/him)?
By mistake, apparently :sweat_smile:

Boolean rings are maybe named liked this because if you put xâˆ¨y:=x+xy+yx \vee y := x + xy + yxâˆ¨y:=x+xy+y, and Â¬x=x+1\neg x = x+1Â¬x=x+1, then you get a boolean algebra. But without the commutativity, it seems difficult to prove anything. We nevertheless have at least (xâˆ¨y)âˆ¨z=xâˆ¨(yâˆ¨z)(x \vee y) \vee z = x \vee (y \vee z)(xâˆ¨y)âˆ¨z=xâˆ¨(yâˆ¨z) in an idempotent rig. As @Toby Bartels wrote on the nLab page Boolean rig, it seems difficult to prove these kind of order-theoretic/boolean properties without further assumptions.

But so, knowing everything about the free idempotent rig on two generators would be very interesting ahah.
I edited my question on Mathstodon so it doesn't put Morgan on the spot for claiming 3 = 1.
The identity a+ab+ba+b=a+ba+ab+ba+b=a+ba+ab+ba+b=a+b looks useful.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Boolean rings are maybe named liked this because if you put xâˆ¨y:=x+xy+yx \vee y := x + xy + yxâˆ¨y:=x+xy+y, and Â¬x=x+1\neg x = x+1Â¬x=x+1, then you get a boolean algebra. But without the commutativity, it seems difficult to prove anything. We nevertheless have at least (xâˆ¨y)âˆ¨z=xâˆ¨(yâˆ¨z)(x \vee y) \vee z = x \vee (y \vee z)(xâˆ¨y)âˆ¨z=xâˆ¨(yâˆ¨z) in an idempotent rig. As Toby Bartels wrote on the nLab page Boolean rig, it seems difficult to prove these kind of order-theoretic/boolean properties without further assumptions.

But so, knowing everything about the free idempotent rig on two generators would be very interesting ahah.

Well, well, with 4=24=24=2 I'm gonna recheck these things.

Wonderfull, using 4=24=24=2, you also get, by defining xâˆ§y:=Â¬(Â¬xâˆ¨Â¬y)=2x+2y+xy+2x \wedge y := eg( eg x \vee eg y) = 2x+2y+xy+2xâˆ§y:=Â¬(Â¬xâˆ¨Â¬y)=2x+2y+xy+2, that (xâˆ§y)âˆ§z=xâˆ§(yâˆ§z)(x \wedge y) \wedge z = x \wedge (y \wedge z)(xâˆ§y)âˆ§z=xâˆ§(yâˆ§z).
I would want to know what properties of skew lattices you get.
Sadly, you don't even get xâˆ¨x=xx \vee x = xxâˆ¨x=x or xâˆ§x=xx \wedge x = xxâˆ§x=x...
4=24=24=2, also gives Â¬Â¬Â¬Â¬x=Â¬Â¬x eg eg eg eg x = eg eg xÂ¬Â¬Â¬Â¬x=Â¬Â¬x..., so by iterating negations, you only get x,Â¬x,Â¬Â¬xx, eg x, eg eg xx,Â¬x,Â¬Â¬x and Â¬Â¬Â¬x eg eg eg xÂ¬Â¬Â¬x
If we work out a systematic method for how big the free idempotent rig is, it would be fun to submit the first few values to the OEIS

For no generators we get two elements; if I haven't missed any identities then for one generator we get 13:
{0,a,2a,3a,1,1+a,1+2a,2,2+a,2+2a,3,3+a,3+2a}\{0,a,2a,3a,1,1+a,1+2a,2,2+a,2+2a,3,3+a,3+2a\}{0,a,2a,3a,1,1+a,1+2a,2,2+a,2+2a,3,3+a,3+2a}
and the current upper bound for two generators is over 2000.
The free idempotent rig on 3 generators is probably infinite, because the free idempotent monoid on 3 generators is:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square-free_word

Aha, beware @John Baez, according to @Tim Campion 's link earlier, the free idempotent monoid on any number of generators is actually finite: it's not simply the set of squarefree words, since there can be non-trivial identities between these. Counterintuitive!

Interesting -- I hadn't appreciated this before -- it seems to be a quite nontrivial claim that the free idempotent monoid F(x,y,z)F(x,y,z)F(x,y,z) on 3 generators is finite. So I suppose a general element of F(x,y,z)F(x,y,z)F(x,y,z) must typically have infinitely many representations as a square-free word. Whatever references that OEIS page has must have some interesting methods to study this sort of thing...
